description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must fulfill their Sixth Amendment obligations and ensure a high-quality system of indigent defense. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Plank 3: Ensure an effective right to counsel

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Constitution requires that people charged with a crime be represented by a lawyer, even if they cannot afford one. The current reality falls woefully short of this guarantee. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"More than 80 percent of people charged with felony offenses cannot afford a private lawyer and must rely on under-resourced systems of indigent defense, including overstretched public defenders with crushing caseloads, contract attorneys, or other forms of court-appointed counsel.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These indigent defense systems “exist in a state of crisis.” In some cases, people lack counsel entirely. In others, people are responsible for paying for counsel through fees they cannot afford. When counsel is provided, it is often in name only — lawyers who have too many cases, too little time, few resources for investigation and mitigation, and/or financial conflicts that make zealous advocacy impossible. These patchwork systems fail the most vulnerable in our society and contravene our constitutional obligation to provide a lawyer to everyone accused of a crime. They lead to more jail time and less justice. Instead, we must ensure prosecutions do not take place without a system of public defenders’ offices that have the resources and expertise to provide dedicated representation to anyone who is charged with a crime. Only then will the constitution’s guarantee of effective counsel be fully realized.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure that no one is prosecuted without provisions such that public defenders have manageable caseloads and resources to provide diligent, high-quality services for all clients at trial and on appeal.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Support and promote efforts that ensure parity in funding, pay, attorney and investigator staffing, and resources for indigent defense vis-a-vis law enforcement and prosecution.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must stop criminalizing poverty and start using treatment, community investments, and social supports to address social problems.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
